\newpage
\section*{Diagram of large cardinal properties}
Under suitable consistency assumptions, large cardinal properties that appear in higher positions on this diagram have strictly higher consistency strength than properties appearing lower down the diagram.

% https://q.uiver.app/#
\[\begin{tikzcd}
	&&& {\kappa \text{ Reinhardt}} & {0=1} \\
	&&& I1 \\
	&&& I3 \\
	&&& {\kappa \text{ supercompact}} \\
	&&& {\kappa \text{ strongly compact}} \\
	{} & {\begin{tabular}{c}\text{large}\\\text{medium}\end{tabular}} &&&&& {} \\
	&&& {\kappa \text{ strong}} \\
	&&& {\mathsf{Surv}(\kappa)} \\
	&& {\kappa \text{ Ulam}} & {\mathsf{M}(\kappa)} & {\mathsf{RVM}(\kappa)} \\
	{} & {\begin{tabular}{c}\text{medium}\\\text{small}\end{tabular}} &&&&& {} \\
	&& {\mathsf{WC}(\kappa)} & {\mathsf{W}(\kappa)} \\
	&&& {\mathsf{I}(\kappa)} & {\mathsf{WI}(\kappa)} \\
	&&& {\mathsf{Wor}(\kappa)}
	\arrow[from=9-4, to=9-5]
	\arrow[from=9-5, to=12-5]
	\arrow[from=9-4, to=11-4]
	\arrow[from=11-4, to=12-4]
	\arrow[from=12-4, to=12-5]
	\arrow[from=12-4, to=13-4]
	\arrow[tail reversed, from=11-3, to=11-4]
	\arrow[shift left=2, from=9-4, to=9-3]
	\arrow["{\text{min.}}", shift left=2, from=9-3, to=9-4]
	\arrow[from=8-4, to=9-4]
	\arrow[from=7-4, to=8-4]
	\arrow[from=5-4, to=7-4]
	\arrow[from=4-4, to=5-4]
	\arrow[from=3-4, to=4-4]
	\arrow[from=2-4, to=3-4]
	\arrow[from=1-4, to=2-4]
	\arrow[tail reversed, from=1-4, to=1-5]
	\arrow[dotted, no head, from=10-1, to=10-7]
	\arrow[dotted, no head, from=6-1, to=6-7]
\end{tikzcd}\]

% inacc -/> worldly: Skolem
% W -/> I: reflection KEP
% M -/> W: reflection, same for surv and strong to surv and measurable
% SC -> strong on ES3 46--48, shows how to make strongly compact cardinals embedding cardinals

% "small large cardinals" are usually considered those cardinals consistent with V=L, and these cardinals are usually downwards absolute
% note that L is minimal; if V=L + {U is a kappa-complete nonprincipal uf on kappa}, then form the ultrapower embedding, but by minimality j_U must be L -> L. But we showed that M \neq V for ultrapower embeddings. So L has no measurable cardinals.

% Woodin cardinals, which sit between strong and strongly compact cardinals, represent another boundary between sizes of large cardinal axioms, just like measurables. These are crucial for understanding the connection between large cardinals and infinite games.
% Cardinals less than Woodin cardinals are called `medium-sized large cardinals', and things above them are `large large cardinals'.
% Above Woodin cardinals, we know very little.
